text: I stayed silent, gripping the counter tightly as I watched the situation unfold. The drunkard’s temper only flared higher, like fire fed with oil.
He suddenly grabbed the bottle and smashed it to the ground. Shards and liquor exploded outward, forcing me to take two steps back from the shock.
The crowd screamed, and the hearth’s flames trembled. The stench of alcohol mixed with dust filled the air, making me cough.
At that instant, a fierce wind roared in from outside, snuffing out half the firelight.
Cold air swirled with snow mist into the room, and with it stepped in a figure draped in a silver-white cloak. Her very presence froze the air.
The cloaked woman’s gaze was calm yet razor-sharp. With a single motion, both the flying shards and the wind froze midair.
Her voice cut through the storm—clear and commanding: “That’s enough.”
The drunkard stiffened where he stood, his face draining of color. With a hoarse gasp, he turned and stumbled out the door.
I remained leaning against the counter, chest heaving. A shallow cut on my hand oozed blood, glinting crimson in the firelight.
She looked at me. Her gaze was as light as the wind—yet carried a weight I could barely endure.
“Next time, don’t wait so long,” she said softly.
Before I could answer, she had already turned away. The snow mist parted behind her and faded into the night.
